docs.title: Deep Notes
docs.text:
Welcome to Deep Notes – DeepThinkJo.

Deep Notes is my personal, textbook-style knowledge base. It collects concise, carefully curated notes on:

  • Mathematics
  • Computer Science
  • Artificial Intelligence

Each note is written not as a casual memo, but as a mini textbook page: formal structure first, then my own explanations and intuitions.

docs.title: 1. What is Deep Notes?
docs.text:
Deep Notes is a long-term project with three main goals:

  1. Rebuild core concepts in my own words Especially for Mathematics, I write definitions, theorems, and proofs in LaTeX, then add my own commentary under each block.

  2. Keep everything version-controlled and reproducible Notes are written in Notion, synced automatically to GitHub as Markdown, and published here via MkDocs + GitHub Pages.

  3. Expose my learning process publicly Anyone (including future me) can browse, search, and build on top of this knowledge.

docs.title: 2. How to Use This Site
docs.text:
Use the navigation to browse by category:

  • Mathematics
  • Textbook-style notes with formal Definition / Theorem / Proof blocks.

  • Each block is followed by my own explanation in plain language.

  • Computer Science

  • Programming, data structures, algorithms.

  • Conceptual explanations, pseudocode, and sometimes implementations.

  • Artificial Intelligence

  • Machine Learning and Deep Learning concepts.
  • Focus on mechanisms, math behind models, and practical intuition.

Each note follows a consistent internal structure:

  1. Overview – Why this concept matters and where it appears.
  2. Key Concepts – Core definitions, ideas, and objects.
  3. Main Content – Detailed explanations, derivations, examples, and proofs.
  4. Summary – Final recap and future review points.

docs.title: 3.1 Mathematics
docs.text:
Mathematics notes are written in a textbook-like style.

  • Formal Definition / Theorem / Lemma / Corollary / Proof blocks (using LaTeX)
  • Below each block there is a short “Your Explanation” section where I restate the idea in my own words and intuition.

Typical topics include:

  • Linear Algebra (vector spaces, linear transformations, matrices, eigenvalues, …)
  • Calculus (limits, derivatives, integrals, series, …)
  • Probability and Statistics (random variables, distributions, estimators, …)

Conceptually, a page often looks like this:

```text Definition -> my explanation

Theorem -> my explanation

Proof -> proof intuition

Example -> my interpretation

docs.title: 3.2 Computer Science
docs.text:
CS notes focus on:

  • Data structures and algorithms
  • Complexity and invariants
  • Implementation details (mainly Python, sometimes C)

Typical content includes:

  • Problem definition
  • Algorithm idea and pseudocode
  • Complexity analysis
  • Sample implementation
  • My own explanation of why it works and how to think about it.

docs.title: 3.3 Artificial Intelligence
docs.text:
AI notes are centered around:

  • Machine learning concepts (loss functions, optimization, regularization, …)
  • Deep learning architectures (MLP, CNN, RNN, Transformer, …)
  • Training dynamics and practical tricks.

Each AI note usually contains:

  • Intuitive description of the model or method
  • Mathematical formulation (when needed)
  • Mechanism / forward–backward process
  • Example or simple experiment idea
  • Summary of when to use it and why.

docs.title: 4. Workflow: From Notion to This Site
docs.text:
The content on this site is not written directly in Markdown.

Instead, the workflow is:

  1. I write notes in Notion, inside a structured database.
  2. A sync script reads the Notion database via API and exports pages as Markdown.
  3. The Markdown files are stored in the notes/ folder of the Deep_Notes repository.
  4. MkDocs builds this site from those Markdown files.
  5. GitHub Actions automatically deploys the site to GitHub Pages.

This means:

  • Every note here has a corresponding Notion page.
  • Updates in Notion eventually propagate here.
  • Everything is version-controlled and open.

docs.title: 5. Roadmap
docs.text:
This project is still evolving. Planned improvements include:

  • Better navigation by topic and difficulty level
  • A consistent style for all mathematics notes
  • More examples and diagrams for abstract concepts
  • Improved theming and typography (e.g. MkDocs Material)
  • Search and SEO tuning for easier discovery

docs.title: 6. About DeepThinkJo
docs.text:
I am DeepThinkJo (조승환), a learner aiming to become an AI engineer and researcher.

Deep Notes is my way of:

  • Thinking slowly and precisely about core ideas
  • Making my learning process transparent
  • Building a personal reference that I can trust and reuse

If you are reading this, you are welcome to explore, learn, and build on these notes.

docs.title: Chapter 1 — Python Basics
docs.text:
Programming is a fundamental tool in computer science and AI engineering.

It allows us to transform abstract ideas—algorithms, models, and problem-solving strategies—into precise instructions that a computer can execute.

Among many programming languages, Python stands out for its clarity, simplicity, and expressive power.

It is easy for beginners to learn while remaining powerful enough for scientific computing, data analysis, and machine learning.

This chapter introduces the essential elements of Python programming.

The goal is not only to learn syntax, but to develop the ability to:

  • understand program structure
  • represent data effectively
  • control program behavior with logic
  • write clear and reusable code
  • think computationally These foundations are necessary before studying algorithms, data structures, numerical methods, or machine learning.

By completing this chapter, you will be prepared for more advanced topics in computer science and AI engineering.

docs.title: What is a Program, Programming, and a Programmer?
docs.text:
• Program: A sequence of instructions written to solve a problem.
  • Programming: The process of designing and writing programs.
  • Programmer: A person who solves problems with programming.

docs.title: Computer Architecture and Levels of Abstraction
docs.text:
A computer can be viewed as a layered system:

Physics → Hardware → Assembly Language → Programming Languages → Software

  • Lower layers are low-level and machine-oriented.
  • Upper layers are high-level and human-oriented.

docs.title: Programming Languages
docs.text:
A programming language acts as an interface between humans and computers. It must be:

  • readable and expressive for humans,

  • translatable into low-level instructions for machines. High-level programs cannot be executed directly. They must be translated into lower-level code. Two major translation approaches are described below:

  • Interpreter: Executes code line by line (e.g., Python).

  • Compiler: Converts the entire program into machine code before execution (e.g., C/C++). Both approaches bridge the gap between human-written instructions and computer-executable operations.

docs.title: What Kind of Language Is Python?
docs.text:
Python is a high-level, general-purpose programming language focused on readability and simplicity.

It abstracts low-level details and is executed through an interpreter, allowing rapid feedback and iterative development.

docs.title: Key Characteristics of Python
docs.text:
1. Readable and Clean Syntax
  2. High-Level Abstraction
  3. Rich Standard Library
  4. Support for Multiple Paradigms
  5. Strong Object-Oriented Model
  6. Portability across Platforms
  7. Extensible and Embeddable
  8. Large Ecosystem and Community

docs.title: Values
docs.text:
A value is a piece of data that a program manipulates.

Examples include:

  • 42 (integer)
  • 3.14 (float)
  • "hello" (string)
  • True, False (boolean) Conceptually, each value is stored somewhere in the computer's memory.

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
A variable is a name that refers to a value.

When you write:

```plain text x = 10

Python stores the value 10 in memory and then binds the name x to that value.

You can think of a variable as a human-readable label pointing to a location in memory that holds some value:

- the value is the actual data stored in memory
- the variable is a name referring to that data
Python internally manages memory addresses, so programmers focus on names and values rather than raw pointers.

Example:

```plain text
x = 5
x = "now a string"
The variable name x now refers to a different value in memory.

docs.title: Types
docs.text:
Every value has a type, which determines what operations can be performed on it.

Common built-in types:

  • int – integers
  • float – real numbers
  • bool – boolean values
  • str – strings
  • NoneType – the type of None You can inspect the type of a value using:

```plain text type(42) type("hello")

## Dynamic Typing

Python uses dynamic typing, meaning:

- variables do not have fixed types
- a variable’s type depends on the value it currently refers to
- type changes occur at runtime
Example:

```plain text
x = 10
x = 3.14
x = "text"

docs.title: Type Conversion
docs.text:
You can convert between types when appropriate:

```plain text int("42") float("3.5") str(100)

Invalid conversions raise errors:

```plain text
int("hello")  # ValueError

docs.title: Boolean Contexts
docs.text:
Python evaluates values in a boolean context when using conditionals.

The following values evaluate to False:

  • 0, 0.0
  • "" (empty string)
  • [], {}, set() (empty containers)
  • None
  • False Everything else is treated as True.

Example:

```plain text if []: print("True") else: print("False")

```

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
```plain text Definition. Write the formal definition clearly using LaTeX.

Example: Let V be a vector space. A subset W ⊆ V is a subspace if 1. 0 ∈ W, 2. x, y ∈ W ⇒ x + y ∈ W, 3. a ∈ F, x ∈ W ⇒ ax ∈ W.

### Your Explanation (Intuitive Commentary)

- Intuition behind the definition
- Why this formulation matters
- How to interpret it in your own words
### Theorem

```plain text
**Theorem.**
State the theorem precisely using LaTeX.

Example:
If T : V → W is linear, then Ker(T) and Range(T) are subspaces.

docs.title: Your Explanation
docs.text:
• Meaning of the theorem
  • Why it works / intuition
  • When and where it is useful

docs.title: Proof
docs.text:
```plain text Proof. Write the formal proof. You may use block math:

\[ T(u + v) = T(u) + T(v) \] 
### Proof Intuition

- Key idea of the argument
- High-level reasoning
### Remark

```plain text
**Remark.**
Notes, cautions, extensions, or special cases.

  • Summary of theorems:
  • One-sentence intuition:
  • What to review later:

docs.title: 1. What is Linear Algebra?
docs.text: Linear algebra is the mathematical framework that provides tools and strategies for solving real-world engineering problems that exhibit linearity.

docs.title: Core Tools (Objects)
docs.text:
• Vectors
  • Linear Transformations
  • Matrices

docs.title: Core Strategies (Methods)
docs.text:
• Linear Systems
  • Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
  • Determinants
  • Diagonalization
  • Norms and Inner Products
  • Orthogonality
  • Projections and Least Squares In short, linear algebra allows us to model, analyze, and solve linear structures that appear across engineering and science.

docs.title: 2. Why Is Linear Algebra Important?
docs.text:
Engineering problems, once mathematically modeled, typically fall into one of two categories:

  1. Problems that are inherently linear

  2. Nonlinear problems that can be approximated or transformed into linear ones Studying linear algebra equips an engineer with the ability to:

  3. Determine whether a problem exhibits linearity

  4. Apply linearization techniques to nonlinear problems
  5. Use linear structures to analyze stability, solvability, and behavior
  6. Employ matrix and vector tools to compute solutions efficiently Linear algebra is therefore a universal language for engineering problem solving.

It is foundational in fields such as control engineering, structural analysis, optimization, circuits, signal processing, and more.

docs.title: 3. How Linear Algebra Is Used in AI / ML / DL
docs.text:
Modern AI systems rely heavily on linear operations, vector spaces, and matrix factorizations.

Below are representative examples:

docs.title: ● Linear Regression
docs.text:
y^=Xβ\hat{y} = X\beta

\[y\]

y^=Xβ

Solution:

β=(XTX)−1XTy\beta = (X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty

β=(XTX)−1XTy

Key concepts: column space, rank, invertibility

docs.title: ● Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
docs.text:
Σv=λv\Sigma v = \lambda v

Σv=λv

  • The principal components correspond to eigenvectors of the covariance matrix
  • Based on: eigenvalues, orthogonality, spectral decomposition

docs.title: ● Neural Networks (MLP)
docs.text:
A single layer computes

y=Wx+by = Wx + b

y=Wx+b

→ A pure linear transformation

Neural networks stack sequences of linear and nonlinear transformations.

Key concepts: matrix multiplication, norms, Jacobians, Hessians

docs.title: ● Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)
docs.text: Convolution is a linear operation, representable by Toeplitz matrices.

docs.title: ● Transformers / Self-Attention
docs.text:
Attention(Q,K,V)=softmax(QKTd)V\text{Attention}(Q,K,V) = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^T}{\sqrt{d}}\right)V

Attention(Q,K,V)=softmax(d

QKT)V

This mechanism relies on inner products and matrix multiplication.

docs.title: ● Optimization
docs.text:
• Gradient Descent uses local linear approximations
  • Newton’s Method uses the inverse of the Hessian matrix
  • Quadratic forms and positive-definite matrices arise naturally

    Most ML/DL algorithms are sequences of linear operations interwoven with nonlinearities.

docs.title: 4. How This Note Series Is Structured
docs.text: There are two common ways linear algebra textbooks organize their material:

docs.title: (1) Begin with abstract vector spaces, then introduce matrices
(2) Begin with Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, then generalize to abstract vector spaces
docs.text: This series follows Approach (1).

docs.title: Reasons:
docs.text:
• Avoids restricting vectors to numerical lists
  • Includes function spaces, polynomial spaces, signal spaces, etc.
  • Matches how AI engineers think about embedding spaces and feature spaces
  • A more general perspective offers broader modeling capabilities

docs.title: Flow of This Note Series:
docs.text:
1. Vector Spaces
  2. Linear Transformations
  3. Matrix Representations
  4. Applications in Engineering and AI

docs.title: 5. Notation
docs.text: This series follows the notation used in the author’s linear algebra notes.

docs.title: Fields & Spaces
docs.text:
• R\mathbb{R}R: real numbers
  • C\mathbb{C}C: complex numbers
  • Bold lowercase: vectors (x, v)
  • Bold uppercase: matrices (A, B)
  • eie_iei: standard basis vectors

docs.title: Subspaces
docs.text:
• Span(S)\text{Span}(S)Span(S): span
  • Ker(T)\text{Ker}(T)Ker(T): kernel
  • Range(T)\text{Range}(T)Range(T): image
  • Nul(A)={x∣Ax=0}\text{Nul}(A) = {x \mid Ax = 0}Nul(A)={x∣Ax=0}
  • Col(A)\text{Col}(A)Col(A): column space
  • Row(A)\text{Row}(A)Row(A): row space

docs.title: Operators
docs.text:
• det⁡(A)\det(A)det(A): determinant
  • tr⁡(A)\operatorname{tr}(A)tr(A): trace
  • rank⁡(A)\operatorname{rank}(A)rank(A): rank
  • ATA^TAT: transpose
  • A*A^*A*: conjugate transpose

docs.title: Inner Products & Norms
docs.text:
• ⟨x,y⟩\langle x, y \rangle⟨x,y⟩: inner product
  • ∥x∥|x|∥x∥: Euclidean norm
  • ∥A∥F|A|_F∥A∥F: Frobenius norm

docs.title: Linear Transformations
docs.text:
• T:V→WT : V \to WT:V→W
  • [T]B[T]_B[T]B: matrix representation w.r.t. basis BBB
  • λi\lambda_iλi: eigenvalues
  • viv_ivi: eigenvectors
  • SVD: A=UΣVTA = U\Sigma V^TA=UΣVT
